required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Does Preoperative Tamsulosin Facilitate Semi-rigid Ureteroscopic Management of Lower Ureteric Calculi Prospective, Randomized Double Blind Study

brief_summary.textblock:
Ureteric calculi are one of the most common reasons for frequent Urolithiasis. The estimated prevalence is 8-13% of all calculi.
Medical expulsive therapy (MET) is recommended by the European Association of Urology (EAU) (2013) for 5-10 mm ureteric stones to facilitate stone passage. For MET, alpha blockers, mainly tamsulosin, have shown efficacy in several randomized controlled trials. The underlying pathophysiology of this therapy is supported by the presence and distribution of adrenoreceptors in the ureter. Blocking the action of alpha-1 receptors by pharmacological agents (alpha blockers), such as alfuzosin, terazosin, doxazosin, and, most typically, tamsulosin, results in the relaxation of the ureteric smooth muscle.
Ureteroscopy (URS) is the most commonly performed procedure for the treatment of ureteral calculi, with a high (>90%) stone-free rate after a single treatment. Advancing a rigid ureteroscope into a non-dilated ureter may be difficult and cause complications. Ureteric dilatation may provide access to stones, but not in all cases, and ureteral mucosal injury up to perforation might occur.

detailed_description.textblock: Based on the role of alpha blockers, mainly tamsulosin, in MET of ureteric calculus, the investigator will attempt to extend the use of alpha blockers prior to URS for procedural ease. the investigator will conduct a prospective, randomized double-blind study to evaluate whether alpha blockers facilitate the negotiation of the ureteroscope if administered preoperatively.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of patients develop spontaneous expulsion of stone
primary_outcome.description: the stone spontaneously expelled without intervension

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients showing dilated ureteric orifice
primary_outcome.description: during ureteroscopy easy introduction in the ureter

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients need dilatation below stone
primary_outcome.description: difficult introduce the ureteroscope and reach the stone

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients need dormia extraction or forceps without disintegration
primary_outcome.description: that is due to dilated ureter so easy remove the stone

primary_outcome.measure: Time of operation from introduction of ureteroscope until stone extraction
primary_outcome.description: to know how easy introduction and expulsion of the ureteroscope

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of patients developed side effect from tamsulosin
secondary_outcome.description: any side effect from alpha blocker
any compliction during ureteroscopy such as perforation

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients show failure of ureteroscopy
secondary_outcome.description: failed introduction or extraction of stone

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients show residual stone post ureteroscopy
secondary_outcome.description: difficulty in expulsion of all stones

arm_group.description: people who given placebo to become agroup of comparison with the other group
people who given tamsulosin to know the effect on ureteroscopy and compare with the control group

intervention.description: endoscopic treatment of ureteric stones by extraction or peumatic desintegration or laser

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Lower ureteral stone.
- Age: 18 - 75 years.
- normal renal function.
- single sided ureteral stone with normal other kideny.
- sign the informed consent.
- Be willing/able to adhere to follow up visits.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Upper and middle ureteral stones.
- renal impairment.
- Age < 18 years or 75 < years.
- female who were pregnant
- bilateral ureteric stone or solitary kidney.
- urinary tract infection need drainage.
